Caption:
“It is five in the morning. The only light comes from outside of the windows. Their apartment is right by the intersection of one of Qufu’s biggest roads, the one which circles around the city and divides its tourist attractions from the rest of the town. They are south of the commercial street which regularly gets tour buses visiting the temple and graveyard of 孔子, or Confucius. Drunks sleep on that street. Their shouts, as well as the occasional drunk men looking for prostitutes, disturb Mother’s rest, but what usually wakes Mother up is Father drifting from the bed to ready himself for work. He would carefully fold open the sheet and tiptoe in his slippers to the bathroom, but would have to turn a light on to properly navigate it. That would almost always wake Mother up. If it was early in the morning she would close her eyes and pretend to be sleeping; if it was late enough in the morning she would get up and start her cooking.”

Yesterday Father retired. Mother wakes up, and sees her husband in bed. 

What’s it like, to see this man, who will no longer be going to work, but spending time only with her at the home?  Check out this portrayal of a serene Shandong morning, over at https://www.girar.world/chapter?id=234

Caption:
Mulan, A Shadow of Destiny 命运的阴影

Hua Mulan stood in the silence of the battlefield, her armor soaked in the blood of enemies and comrades alike. She had fought not for glory, but to spare her father from death, yet each step she took deeper into war felt like a step away from the girl she once was. In the dead of night, she would lay awake, haunted by the faces of those she had killed, the weight of her father’s sword heavy in her hands. The shadow of destiny clung to her like a suffocating fog, reminding her that she could never turn back. Even as the soldiers praised her victories, her heart ached with the emptiness of a path chosen not for herself but for the sake of duty.

As the war dragged on, Mulan’s soul became hollow, consumed by the unrelenting burden of her sacrifice. She could not return to her old life, for the person she had been was gone, lost in the haze of battle. Her once-bright spirit was dimmed, replaced by the quiet sorrow of a destiny she never asked for. She had become a warrior and a hero, but in doing so, she had buried her own heart beneath layers of grief and guilt. When she finally returned home, there were no words that could erase the shadow that followed her—a shadow of a destiny that had claimed her future, leaving nothing behind but the ghost of the woman she could have been.

Caption:
To die what you live for
未知生， 焉之死

I have been struggling with my identity for my whole life, I  decided not to suppress my feelings of being able to write Chinese in public. I want to collaborate into my works to celebrate my identity and where I came from. For a long time, I feel ashamed of being who I am. I still remember the fear of not being able to speak English when I first arrived in Canada and struggle to make any friends. I think art was the only thing I could escape from my reality. I hope it will help me to go through some tough time

Caption:
📚 The Ancient Education System in China

China's ancient education system is one of the oldest and most influential in the world. It laid the foundation for the country's rich intellectual and cultural heritage.

🏫 Early Beginnings: Education in China dates back to the Xia Dynasty (2070-1600 BC), where formal schools were established to educate the sons of nobility. These early schools focused on teaching the "Six Arts": ritual, music, archery, chariot racing, calligraphy, and mathematics

📜 Confucian Influence: The teachings of Confucius (551-479 BC) played a crucial role in shaping Chinese education. Confucianism emphasized moral integrity, respect for elders, and the importance of education for personal and societal development

🎓 Imperial Examinations: During the Sui Dynasty (581-618 AD), the imperial examination system was established to select government officials based on merit rather than birthright. This system was further refined during the Tang Dynasty (618-907 AD) and became a cornerstone of Chinese education for over a thousand years

🏛️ State and Village Schools: By the Zhou Dynasty (1046-256 BC), schools were divided into state schools for the nobility and village schools for commoners. State schools offered higher education, while village schools provided basic education

📖 Classical Texts: Students were required to study the "Four Books" and "Five Classics," which included works like the Analects of Confucius and the Book of Rites. Mastery of these texts was essential for success in the imperial examinations

China's ancient education system not only promoted intellectual growth but also instilled values of duty, respect, and moral responsibility. Its legacy continues to influence modern education systems around the world.

#AncientChina #EducationHistory #Confucianism #ImperialExaminations #CulturalHeritage

Caption: Is Wisdom Common Sense? Is Common Sense Wisdom? Right, Wrong. Male, Female. Human, Animal. Black, White. Alive, Dead. The West seems confused, and the majority lack sensical thinking and intelligence. Glad some parts of the world still think and act logically. The Taipei Confucius Temple is modeled after the original Confucius Temple in Qufu, China. The ethical core of Confucianism is a strong belief in meritocracy and the Mandate of Heaven.  It promotes the behaviour of a superior person (君子 jūnzǐ), the Five Constants (五常 Wǔcháng – humaneness, righteousness, proper rite, knowledge and integrity) and The Four (四字 Sìzì– loyalty, filial piety, continence and righteousness). A Confucian should be honest, forgiving, neat, brave, kind-hearted, reverent, frugal and modest.  Confucius’ values of simplicity are echoed throughout the temples build to honour the Great Sage.  You pass through the simple gate and into the first courtyard area of the temple.  The front of the space is on your right as you enter and is dominated by the Wall of Supreme Knowledge (萬仞宮牆 Wàn Rèn Gōng Qiáng). This wall acts as a spirit screen and is emblazoned with a Chinese Unicorn (麒麟 qílín). This auspicious animal is said to appear before sages are born and, according to legend, one materialised before Confucius was born.  The wall itself is deeply symbolic.  It represents the profundity of the teachings of Confucius.  It shows that you cannot easily gain the knowledge and that you must strive hard to learn. ❤️🇹🇼🙏🏻#confucius #confucianism #temple #templesoftheworld #taipei #taiwan #history #architecture #art #taoism #buddhism #culture #confuciustemple #corporatemercenary #wisdom #explore #beautiful #love #travelblogger #travel #traveltheworld #fitfam #wanderlust #style #instatravel #travelgram #globetrotter #travelphotography #traveling #ninjaronz

Caption:
✨A NEW ERA OF IDEAS MATTER IS HERE✨

In 2020, I discovered the work of Canadian political theorist, Daniel A. Bell. I was stunned to read an Oxford-educated philosopher arguing that liberal democracy is not the only legitimate form of government. Being primarily educated in International Relations at this time, I was submersed in the Fukuyamist mindset that liberal democracy was humanity's final socio-political destination. To read someone persuasively rejecting that idea with calm and cultural sensitivity really opened my eyes to the potential of political theory applied to international politics. 

In 2021, I was fortunate enough to have Bell as my thesis supervisor while I studied at Schwarzman College at Tsinghua University. 

Fast forward to today, and Bell joins me on the Ideas Matter podcast as my first academic guest. 

Going forward, I will be interviewing academics about their recent publications. This new format will help me release episodes more regularly. 

The first episode with Daniel Bell is now live wherever you listen to podcasts. 🔗in bio 

Who else would you like to see interviewed on the podcast? Comment below

Caption:
Did you know that behind the grandeur of the 14th-century Ming Dynasty lies a fascinating story of a possible connection between Emperor Zhu Yuanzhang and Islam? As the founder of the Ming Dynasty (1368–1398), Zhu maintained a complex relationship with the Muslim community in China. Some historians even suggest that he might have had affiliations with Islam, though this remains debated.

One notable piece of evidence is his poem titled "Baizizan" or "One Hundred Words of Praise," dedicated to the Prophet Muhammad. Through the verses, Zhu expressed admiration for the Prophet and conveyed deeper messages of virtue, humanity, and spirituality. This poem acted as a bridge between the two great traditions of Islam and Confucianism, reflecting their coexistence in the cultural and moral fabric of Ming China.

#MingDynasty #IslamInChina #Confucianism #CulturalHarmony #ZhuYuanzhang #HistoryOfIslam #MuslimHistory #IslamicPoetry #ChineseHistory #ProphetMuhammad #HistoricalConnections #WorldHistory

Caption:
百闻不如一见 bǎi wén bùrǔ yíjiàn
When encountering anything, it is very important to see it with your own eyes and do it with your own hands to gain real understanding and experience.
In real life, due to the influence of many factors, there are many different opinions. If people cannot stick to their own independent thoughts, they will be dominated by the thoughts of others. No matter how many times you hear others say it, it is better to experience it yourself. When dealing with people, you should not only do it when others ask you to do it, but also compete to do it even if others don't ask you to do it. In this way, you will have fun and gain something.

Caption:
🌟 Dive into the depths of human nature with Xunzi! Born in 310 BCE during the Warring States period, this revered Confucian philosopher believed we are not born good but learn to be through education and ritual. His profound insights challenge us to consider: What does it mean to cultivate goodness in a world where we might instinctively stray? 

With 32 impactful essays, Xunzi has crafted a lasting legacy, reshaping Confucian philosophy and sparking conversations that endure to this day. Are you ready to explore the role of education and ritual in moral development?

Share your thoughts below! How does Xunzi’s view of human nature resonate with you? Don’t forget to like, comment, and share this post with fellow philosophy lovers! 

#Xunzi #Confucianism #Philosophy #HumanNature #Education #Ritual #Legacy #ChinesePhilosophy #Wisdom #Influence

Reference: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy entry on Xunzi

Caption:
🌟 Unlocking the Wisdom of Mencius 🌟 

Ever wondered how our nature shapes our moral compass? Mencius, the great philosopher of the Zhou dynasty, argued that "human nature is good." He believed we are all born with innate virtues just waiting to be cultivated! 💖✨ 

Mencius emphasized the importance of education and personal growth, encouraging us to question, debate, and engage with the world around us. His teachings laid the groundwork for the Confucian ideals we cherish today, profoundly influencing Chinese thought for over a millennium. 📚🧠

Join the conversation about how Mencius's profound insights can guide our journey towards a more compassionate and ethical life. What role do you think education plays in nurturing our innate goodness? Let me know in the comments! 💬👇

If you found this inspiring, like this post, share it, and tag your friends who love philosophy!

Caption:
CONFUCIUS:

Due to its emphasis on social conservatism, strict gender roles, and gender hierarchies, followers of Confucianism (historically and in modern nights) have generally not being positive toward the queer community. Confucius, himself, however, never actually lectured on queerness in any of his teachings.

The main reason Confucianism has developed over the millennia to take on a strong anti-LGBT+ stance is because Confucianism is heavily dependent on the structure of a heterosexual family so as to demarcate the rigid rules, obligations, and expecations of each gender and generation within the family. 

Moreover, one needed decendants in order to be venerated in the afterlife with offerings and prayers. Thus, queerness in Confucianism not only disrupted the socio-cultural hierarchy of a family/community but also made having children (whom you needed to sustain you in the afterlife) no longer guaranteed.

Ironically, though, very recently, Confucius' hard-conservative teachings on the family and family structure had been used in the U.S. Supreme Court's majority opinion in the legendary Obergefell v Hodges decision in 2015 that legalized same-sex marriage across the United States. Specifically, Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote, "The centrality of marriage to the human condition makes it unsurprising that the institution has existed for millennia and across civilizations... Confucius taught that marriage lies at the foundation of government.". . .

Caption:
I Ching

The I Ching or Yijing, usually translated Book of Changes or Classic of Changes, is an ancient Chinese divination text that is among the oldest of the Chinese classics. The I Ching was originally a divination manual and turned into a cosmological text with a series of philosophical commentaries known as the Ten Wings.

As a divination text, the I Ching is used for a Chinese form of cleromancy known as I Ching divination in which bundles of yarrow stalks are manipulated to produce sets of six apparently random numbers ranging from 6 to 9. Each of the 64 possible sets corresponds to a hexagram, which can be looked up in the I Ching. The hexagrams are arranged in an order known as the King Wen sequence. The interpretation of the readings found in the I Ching has been discussed and debated over the centuries. Many commentators have used the book symbolically, often to provide guidance for moral decision-making, as informed by Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism. The hexagrams themselves have often acquired cosmological significance and been paralleled with many other traditional names for the processes of change such as yin and yang and Wu Xing.

Part of the canonization of the text bound it to a set of ten commentaries called the Ten Wings. Arguably the most important of the Ten Wings is the Great Commentary (Dazhuan) or Xi ci, which dates to roughly 300 BC. The Great Commentary describes the I Ching as a microcosm of the universe and a symbolic description of the processes of change. By partaking in the spiritual experience of the I Ching, the Great Commentary states, the individual can understand the deeper patterns of the universe. The Great Commentary associates knowledge of the I Ching with the ability to “delight in Heaven and understand fate;” the sage who reads it will see cosmological patterns and not despair in mere material difficulties. Throughout the Ten Wings, there are passages that seem to purposefully increase the ambiguity of the base text, pointing to a recognition of multiple layers of symbolism.

ℹ️Wikipedia - “I Ching”

Caption:
Taipei, Taiwan 🇹🇼 

Only 12 small nations consider Taiwan to be an independent country, including the Vatican, Palau, Eswantini, Tuvalu… yet you could feel the drive towards sovereignty and democratic rule in a rather unsubtle way, similar to Kosovo, and probably even more. From the giant banners, in English, in the main squares, street demonstrations and Americanised venues like hooters and the like, it does feel very intentional. 

Probably my most favourite anti-PRC cultural find is the presence of veggie eateries everywhere, including Japanese matcha houses. It made me regret not staying for longer, because Taipei was truly amazing. If you’re ever in and around China, and get tired of the deep fried pork or perhaps fancy getting closer to Confucianism ethics (and not only), this is the place for you. It is also one of the most gender equal nations in the world, with one of the most comprehensive lgbt legal rights in Asia. The immigration system is a lot more pleasant, too, compared to China. Most importantly, they have collectable stamps, like in Japan. And did I mention they have matcha?

Caption:
🌟 Unveiling the Wisdom of Chinese Ethics 🌟 

Did you know that the teachings of Confucius, Mozi, and modern thinkers are shaping our understanding of ethics today? From the virtues of benevolence and righteousness to the call for universal love, Chinese philosophy offers profound insights into moral living and social harmony.

Explore how ancient philosophies like Confucianism and Mohism emphasize the importance of community and personal cultivation, while modern interpretations tackle the balance between individual rights and social responsibilities. The richness of these traditions invites us to reflect on our own moral compass in today's world.

What ethical principles resonate with you? Share your thoughts in the comments! Let's engage in a conversation about how ancient wisdom can guide contemporary lives.

Caption:
Kim, a 25-year-old corporate worker, often wonders if others are living better lives than her.

She questions who might be making more money, getting better recognition at work or more opportunities.

When Kim feels she’s falling behind her colleagues, those her age job-wise or in her love life, she feels blue and uneasy.

“I’m grateful for what I have -- attending a large conglomerate, being raised in a good family and graduating from a prestigious school. But everything always looks better from afar when we don’t know the story of how other’s grass turned out so green,” she told The Korea Herald.

Tap bio to read full story by Park Jun-hee

Caption:
"Andong Grilled Salted Mackerel"

안동간고등어, Grilled Salted Mackerel with Andong's recipe.

Andong is the city Surrounded by Mountains and has a Historical background for Andong Grilled Salted Mackerel as Andong's Signature Dish. In Joseon Dynasty, Yangban as Nobles could enjoy grilled Fish Only, Not for Commoners. Andong was Populated largely by Yangban(surely their servants as well) and so Grilled Salted Mackerel became Andong's Signature Dish.

Andong Grilled Salted Mackerel needs a period of Ripening. Has Omega-3 fatty Acids, EPA, DHA, Protein, various Vitamins and etc.

Enjoy Taste of Korea through Andong Grilled Salted Mackerel in Andong.

Caption:
"Andong Jjimdak"

안동찜닭, steamed chicken with Andong's recipe.

Koreans are for Chicken. Fried Chicken, Dakgangjeong(Sweet Crispy Korean Fried Boneless Chiken), Marinated Chicken, Spicy Braised Chicken, Grilled Chicken Feet, Grilled Chicken Skewers, Spicy Stir-fried Chicken(Chuncheon style), Hot Chiken Flavor Ramen(No Chiken in!) and etc.

Andong-jjimdak is cooked over high heat and has  less fat. It has various tastes by adding diverse ingredients like Onions, Potatoes, Carrots, Garlics, Chili peppers, Glass noodles with Soy-sauce.

Enjoy Taste of Korea through Andong Jjimdak in Andong.

Caption: The goddess Nüwa is one of the most ancient deities of the Chinese mythology. She is the one who created humanity from yellow clay and taught humans the way of living. When a Great War among gods caused the collapse of the heavenly pillars, she patched the sky with five coloured stones, reinstating order after a great flood and chaos almost destroyed the world. Both her and her brother/husband are described as half snake beings.\n\n#nuwa #nüwa #goddessnüwa #mythology #chinesemythology #chinesemyth #buddhism #confucianism #daoism #fuxi #pangu

Caption: International #journalists enjoyed an #extraordinary live performance—“Fengshan Ceremony” in Tai’an, E China’s #Shandong province. From the Qin Dynasty with its military prowess to the Han Dynasty highlighting #Confucianism and elegant music, from the grandeur of the Tang Dynasty to the artistic Song Dynasty, and finally to the prosperous Qing Dynasty during the Kangxi and Qianlong reigns, each chapter is rich in storytelling and emotional resonance, allowing the audience to traverse 5,000 years of #Chinesehistory in just 80 minutes. #awesomeshandong #charmingshandong

Caption:
The Ballad of Mulan

an anonymous work of Chinese folklore, is dated from the Northern Wei dynasty (386-534 AD), a period marked by significant Silk Road cultural exchanges and the spread of Buddhism, influenced Chinese art, music, and literature, including Mulan's tale. It was first transcribed in the 6th-century "Musical Records of Old and New" by Guo Maoqian during the Song dynasty. 

The ballad embodies key Confucian principles such as Xiao (family devotion) and loyalty (zhong). Confucius (551-479 BC) was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings on ethics and proper conduct, recorded in the "Analects," have profoundly shaped Chinese culture and emphasized social harmony through respect and integrity. These values emphasize respect for family and duty to the state, which are central themes in Mulan’s decision to enlist in the army to protect her aging father. 

UNIVERSAL TRUTHS: Filial piety, a key Confucian value, highlights the deep respect and loyalty children owe to their parents and ancestors. Today, filial piety remains crucial in modern Chinese culture, often shown by caring for elderly parents and upholding family obligations. Within your own family, do you see filial piety as a core value? Are you prepared to make personal sacrifices to benefit your family members?

Overcoming Gender barriers: The ballad illustrates that personal empowerment and heroism are not confined by gender. Similar themes appear in historical figures like Joan of Arc, who led French troops, and Deborah Sampson, who fought in the American Revolutionary War disguised as a man. The ballad of Mulan ultimately recognizes Mulan’s merit and contributions based on her abilities rather than her gender, advocating for the value of personal achievement and character over rigid gender stereotypes.

Greek Gods and Heroes, our illustrated book with over 130 other full page illustrations, is coming in October to Kickstarter. Please check my links in my linktree in my bio to follow the backerkit page. 🤟❤️🏛😁

Caption:
As a part of our Andong Trip we went to a Hanok Complex on the countryside, that belongs to a Lee Family Clan. There we talked to the family head and walked around the Houses and a bit further to the Nakdong River that was right in front of the Houses. The Nakdong River (낙동강) is actually the longest river in Korea. The old Houses with the river in front and everything surrounded by mountains was probably one of the most beautiful places in Korea we have been to so far. The talk with the family head was interesting, since he is still holding up old family traditions. We were definitely able to feel how confucian traditions play a bigger role in Andong than it does in other parts of the country. Since I am also a Lee I was wondering if my father ever mentioned his surname origin. But Lino never said anything about his surname and neither did Felix, so we don't know which Lee-Clan they (and I) belong to. 

We also went to the Korean Studies Institute in Andong to see the 550 preserved wooden plates that used to be hung up on traditional houses to show the purpose of the buildings or plates that were used for printing books. We even got to print our own sentence with carved wooden plates.

Caption:
The Temple of Literature was founded in 1070 by Emperor Ly Thanh Tong to worship Chinese philosopher Confucius. It then became the first university of Vietnam, also known as the Imperial Academy. Until the colonial period, it had been open for over 700 years and taught hundreds of renowned scholars and mandarins. Despite the ravages of war, the temple still retains its architectural and cultural beauty.
 

- The Well of Heavenly Clarity (square pond) or the Source of the Heavenly Light. Symbolizing a mirror absorbing the universe’s best essence, the pond aided students in self-reflection and preparation before entering the sacred inner area

-The interior decoration of the sanctuary also depicts ancient Vietnamese culture. In the center is a typical altar found in every Vietnamese family’s home, always placed in the most sacred place of the house where people worship their ancestors. The altar must contain the five basic elements of Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth, filled with offerings and the smell of incense. On each side of the altar is a pair of cranes and turtles, which symbolize good friends and present a desire for harmony and eternity.

-The temple is featured on the back of the 100,000 Vietnamese đồng banknote

Caption:
Now is finally the time I tell you about my trip to Andong (안동), the capital of Gyeongsangbuk Province (경상북도) and the cradle of korean confucianism. We actually were there in May, but my friend never managed to post anything about our trip. 

On the first day we went to a House Concert at the birthplace of one of the most important confucian scholars of Joseon Dynasty, Toegye Lee Hwang (1501-1570) (퇴계이황) (Toegye is his scholar name). He played a big part in developing and promoting Neo-confucianism in Korea. One of his most important achievements is the founding of the Dosan Seowon (도산서원), a confucian academy that trained scholars to pass the civil state exams (과거). The academy was very renowned since a lot of Lees students passed the incredibly difficult exams. 
Today you can find many roads that have his scholar name, but the easiest way to find him is to look on the 1000 won note.

Although we are not a fan of Confucianism as a system itself, we were really excited to learn more about Confucianism, since it is such a big part of korean history. 

We had a really great time in Andong. I will post another post for our Andong trip, but I probably cannot fit everything that we did in there so I just mention that we also visited a old village called Gunja (군자마을). The first picture is from there since I don't have one from the Academy (my friend was busy dressing up as a scholar and performing a greeting ceremony)

One of the professors who was on the trip with us saw my friend taking a picture of me and he also saw little Leebit dangling from my friends' bag. He thought that we are really cute and even asked to take a picture of little Leebit. That was a very proud father moment for me^^

#leebit #skzoo #leebitskzoo #andong #confucianism #퇴계이황 #toegye

Caption:
Happening Now - We are pleased to have Dr Peter Chang with us this morning to explore the ongoing dialogue between #Islam and #Confucianism in #Malaysia, highlighting the importance for racial harmony in the multi-religious nation. Focusing on Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim’s role in promoting interfaith engagement, both within Malaysia and on a global scale, Dr Chang also discussed Anwar's collaboration with President Xi Jinping on the Global Civilization Initiative and its implications for Malaysia, China, and global issues like the Gaza crisis.

The seminar, titled "Anwar Ibrahim’s Role in Islamic-Confucian Dialogue and its Impact on Malaysia, China and Beyond", is moderated by Dr Hwok-Aun Lee and organised by the Regional Social and Cultural Programme.

Caption:
"Charm" would not be a practical word to forgive her manipulation of him. Then, at first sight, he was enthusiastically distracted by her traditional ao-dai. Remember the time when her purple dress browsed the golden gate of the imperial palace. Who is she? Where is she? – people consider her as being a Muse of Hue, the ancient capital – of Vietnam, who generally embodies the "low-key" beauty of significant land – some express that of Confucianism – whatever ! he obviously falls for her long-black hair winding up with its lap of  Vietnam Ao-dai. 

Somehow, he wants to say just "hi"; nonetheless, "Hi" does not mean to break the ice effortlessly – in sight of the culture to perceive its challenge. It is not similar to numerous non-brain small talks when he got used to hooking up with hot Blondes in New York – Sao Paulo – Naples – Bangkok, and Saigon.

Caption:
◽️In Chinese culture, the concept of the soul has evolved over centuries, with early references dating back to ancient dynasties. One of the key ideas involves the dualism of the soul, expressed through the terms hun (魂) and po (魄).Together, they represent the interconnected but distinct aspects of human existence, integrating both the spiritual and physical elements. This concept continues to influence cultural practices, religious beliefs, and philosophical thought to this day.

▪️In Confucianism the concept ancestor worship though proper funeral practices and rites is often emphasized (the worship and respect for the ancestors through these rituals) can awaken their spirit so that they can bless their descendants with healthy and harmonious life.
▪️Daoism went a step further dividing the human soul in Three Hun and Seven Po (often translated as Three souls and Seven spirits/senses 三魂七魄 sān hún qī pò). The three hun/souls are spiritual essence and the seven po/spirits are linked to one’s emotions. Through self-cultivation and spiritual practices one can achieve spiritual harmony and balance in life.

☁️How did I even get the idea od exploring this or any other “unusual” aspect of Chinese culture? 💡Mostly it comes from learning the language. In this case I was writing a (very very) short plot summery of the Butterfly Lovers legend and I needed to use the word “soul”. I had a vague idea that the right word is linghun 灵魂, but just to be sure I went to look it up in the dictionary. And as you can imagine (if you’re learning Chinese you’ll know what I mean) the whole new world opened to me. I spent some time exploring it and now I’m sharing it with you. Hopefully you’ll find it as interesting as I do!

📝If you’re learning Chinese language here is an interesting and useful idiom 魄散魂飞 (pòsàn-húnfēi be frightened out of one’s wits) Be frightened out of one’s wits 

➡️Swipe for more details about the key elements of hun and po and the Daoist view of this concept

Caption:
Confucius: The Sage of Ancient China

Confucius (551–479 BC) was a renowned Chinese philosopher, teacher, and political figure whose teachings have shaped Eastern philosophy and culture for centuries. Born in the state of Lu (modern-day Qufu, China), he emphasized the importance of morality, social harmony, and virtuous leadership. His wisdom, compiled in the "Analects," promotes values like respect, kindness, and education, offering timeless guidance on living a balanced and ethical life. Confucius's legacy continues to inspire and influence people around the world today.

Caption:
🦉 Comenzamos la semana con este pensamiento del gran maestro y filósofo chino 𝐶𝑜𝑛𝑓𝑢𝑐𝑖𝑜.

Esta frase nos invita a ser perseverantes. 
En la vida podemos tener metas y sueños que cumplir y a veces nos damos por vencidos en cuanto se nos presenta algún obstáculo o cuando todo avanza más lento de lo que nos gustaría.

Cuando tenemos estos tropiezos podemos rendirnos, desanimarnos y darnos por vencidos, pero así nunca lograremos aquello que anhelamos. 
Debemos perseverar aún si caemos en el camino, debemos levantarnos y seguir adelante, así sea poco a poco, un paso a la vez iremos progresando, por pequeño que nos parezca ese avance, dar ese paso hacia adelante nos acercará a nuestro objetivo.

No te rindas, no desesperes, si lo sigues intentando: 
¡Lo lograrás! 🙌

Feliz inicio de semana 🙏

𝐿𝑎𝑢𝑟𝑎 𝑆𝑎𝑙𝑎𝑧𝑎𝑟

Caption:
Throughout its history, Confucianism has garnered multiple ideological opponents. For example, Taoists considered Confucians’ emphasis on ritual and social structures as unnatural. Mohists in turn believed that expensive rites and gradation of affection marked Confucian heritage as superficial. Legalists (most famous Qin Shi Huang, the first historical emperor of China) believed that Confucians’ interest in historical records and the culture of “courtly admonitions” could threaten the royal authority. Lastly, Buddhists associated Confucianism with extreme this-worldism. Finally, in modern era, China, Japan and Korea in particular have noted the general conservatism of Confucian heritage, viewing it as incompatible with social and technological growth and pointing it out as one of the primary factors for the former backwardness of (in particular) China and Korea. In more global contexts, Confucianism is frequently considered to be a deeply anthropocentric philosophy of men, advocating gender segregation and unconditional respect for elders and hierarchies.

.
.
.
.
.
.

Caption:
Pada tanggal 19 Juli – 7 Agustus 2024, tim peneliti dari Universitas Huaqiao, Tiongkok, tiba di Indonesia untuk melanjutkan riset mereka tentang perkembangan agama Khonghucu di Indonesia. Tim ini dipimpin oleh Profesor Wang Aiping, seorang akademisi yang dikenal luas dalam penelitian Khonghucu di Indonesia. Beliau sebelumnya telah meluncurkan sebuah buku pada tahun 2010 yang merupakan disertasi S3-nya, mengupas tuntas tentang agama Khonghucu di Indonesia.

Kunjungan kali ini merupakan langkah lanjutan dari penelitian tersebut, dengan fokus memperdalam pemahaman tentang peran Klenteng dan Litang, sebagai tempat ibadah umat Khonghucu, serta melihat perkembangan terbaru dalam pendidikan agama Khonghucu di sekolah-sekolah Indonesia, terutama dalam konteks pendidikan dan pengajaran. Hasil dari penelitian ini diharapkan dapat memperkaya literatur akademik serta memberikan kontribusi bagi komunitas Khonghucu baik di Indonesia maupun di Tiongkok.

Anggota Rombongan:
Profesor Wang Aiping – Dosen di Universitas Huaqiao, ahli sejarah.
Profesor Lu Jinhuan – Dosen di Universitas Huaqiao, turut serta dalam penelitian.
Mr Luo Shiwen – Chairman Perusahaan Guangxi Qianyi Cultural Communication
Mrs Zhong Manhong – General Manager
Mr Zhao Yu – Wakil General Manager

Dalam kunjungan ke Klenteng dan Litang di Jakarta dan Surabaya, tim melakukan kunjungan ke berbagai Klenteng dan Litang. Mereka berdialog dengan pengurus tempat ibadah untuk menggali informasi tentang praktik keagamaan serta perubahan yang terjadi dalam komunitas Khonghucu.

Lanjut di komen...

~mw (berbagai sumber)

Caption:
Salam Kebajikan, Salam Literasi!

Kami tim Langkah Kecil dengan bangga mempersembahkan penerbitan terjemahan buku pertama kami: KITAB KONGZI JIAYU VOL. 1✨

Disepakati para cendekiawan sebagai pendamping sekaligus pelengkap Kitab Lunyu, kitab ini berisi kumpulan catatan kehidupan dan pemikiran Kongfuzi yang dikemas dalam bentuk cerita dilengkapi dialog di beberapa bagian; mencatat diskusi dan tanya-jawab, ujaran-ujaran, sikap, dan tindakan Kongfuzi terhadap para murid dan orang-orang pada zaman itu.

Kitab ini pertama kali disebutkan dalam Kitab Sejarah Dinasti Han dan menurut beberapa ulasan disusun oleh murid-murid Kongfuzi. Dengan menduplikasi beberapa pembahasan yang tertulis dalam kitab klasik lainnya, menjadikan Kitab Kongzi Jiayu lebih terperinci dan spesifik, bahkan bagi sebagian peneliti dipandang lebih berharga dibandingkan Kitab Lunyu!

Segera dapatkan edisi pertama Kitab Kongzi Jiayu melalui contact person yang tertera, dan mulai ambil satu langkah kecil menuju pribadi yang lebih baik!🙌🏻

"Pepohonan ingin diam namun hembusan angin tak berhenti, anak ingin merawat namun orang tua tak menunggu."

Caption:
📜Sunday read: The I Ching, Eternal Book of Change 📜

For thousands of years, the I Ching has been the cornerstone of wisdom, guiding everything from personal decisions to the fate of nations. 🌏 Known as the Book of Changes, it serves as a philosophical map of the universe, a guide to ethical living, and an oracle for understanding the future—both personal and political.

✨ Across China and East Asia, the I Ching has been the most consulted book, revered for its ability to explain the mysteries of life. Its influence spans across disciplines—shaping literature, art, medicine, cartography, and even the sciences. It has inspired endless commentaries from Confucian, Taoist, Buddhist, and even Christian scholars, each offering a unique interpretation of its timeless wisdom.

📚 In the West, the I Ching has captivated minds for over three centuries, becoming the most recognized Chinese text since the 1950s. Its allure lies in its infinite possibilities—each consultation offering a new perspective, a new answer, a new path.

🐉 The origins of the I Ching, one of the oldest texts in human history, are as mysterious as the wisdom it contains. According to ancient Chinese mythology, the culture hero Fu Xi - a being with the body of a dragon or snake and a human face - unlocked the secrets of the universe by observing the natural world. 🌿

✨ Fu Xi studied the patterns in the sky and on earth: the markings on birds and animals, the movement of clouds, the arrangement of stars, and the textures of rocks. From these observations, he discovered that all things could be reduced to eight trigrams, each composed of three stacked lines, either solid or broken, symbolizing the interplay of yin and yang - the fundamental duality that drives the universe. ☯️

🌍 The eight trigrams represent the forces of nature: 
☰ Qián (Heaven)
☱ Duì (Lake) 
☲ Lí (Fire) 
☳ Zhèn (Thunder) 
☴ Xùn (Wind) 
☵ Kǎn (Water)
☶ Gèn (Mountain)
☷ Kūn (Earth) 
 Together, they form the foundation of the I Ching, a text that has guided humanity through the cycles of change for millennia.

#IChing #BookOfChanges #AncientWisdom #Taoism #Confucianism #Philosophy #SpiritualGuidance #TimelessWisdom #TaoApp
Hashtags: Philosophy, Taoism, TimelessWisdom, Confucianism, BookOfChanges, IChing, TaoApp, AncientWisdom, SpiritualGuidance

Caption:
Our global education teaching resources include a curriculum guide for hit Korean movie The Way Home. This charming story follows 7-year-old Sang-Woo (played by Yoo Seung-Ho in his feature film debut) from the big city, who must stay with his mute grandmother in a small rural village. 

Our classroom-ready lesson plans introduce students to South Korean geography and culture, including Confucianism. The curriculum guide also features lessons about cross-cultural understanding, economics, English language arts, social studies, mathematics (using graphs), media literacy, science, visual arts, and visual literacy, Plus there's a hands-on art activity about making traditional Korean kites!

⭐ Bonus Combo: Extend the conversation about rural living and bring it home with award-winning documentary Greener Pastures, about family farmers in the American Midwest and the challenges of rural life.

Caption: I previously took this post down because I felt a certain way about because I’ve been studying and researching Chinese Martial Arts (Kung/Gung Fu). In the Mortal Kombat games and the new version of the movie, Liu Kang and Kung Lao are Shaolin Monks and I have read a book called SHAOLIN KEMPO and 72 ARTS OF SHAOLIN which were very informative. In the video games and the latest version of the MK movie, both Liu Kang and Kung Lao died. Truth be told, idk why the director or the developers put that in the games and movie. After what I have learned about the Shaolin, they stand for truth and justice; fighting for the weak who can not protect themselves and for peace 🕊️☮️. They stand for the light of this world that shines through the darkness that’ll always take down evil. They have the hearts of a lion 🦁 and the soul of a true warrior, a soul that’ll never die or give up for the fight of justice. The warriors of the light will never lose against those who chose to represent the darkness. The darkness will be terminated/banished from the physical plain of existence to never do harm ever again to those who can’t defend for themselves. #Shaolin #ShaolinMartialArts #KungFu #GungFu #ChineseMixedMartialArts #WuShu #AsoulThatWillNeverDie #TheWay #Daoism #Taoism #Buddhism #Confucius #TheArtOfWar #SunTzu #LaoTzu #iChing #TheBookOfChanges #Confucianism #Philosophy #ChinesePhilosophy

Caption:
Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism are considered the “three pillars” of ancient Chinese society. As philosophies and religions, they not only influenced spirituality, but also government, science, the arts, and social structure. Though their specific beliefs and teachings have occasionally been at odds with each other, there has been much room for overlap. Instead of one tradition taking over and pushing the others out, three philosophies have influenced society alongside each other, changed each other, and at times blended together. Understanding unique interplay between these three traditions gives great insight into ancient Chinese society, as well as modern times.

Though closer to a philosophy than a true religion, Confucianism was a way of life for ancient Chinese people, and it continues to influence Chinese culture today. The founder of Confucianism, named Confucius, lived from 551-479 BC. He was a philosopher and political figure who lived during a time when traditional Chinese principles began to deteriorate under competing political states. He took older religious precepts and translated them into guidelines for social mores. His teachings gave guidance on all levels of ancient Chinese life, from interactions between family members and in the public sphere, to educational standards and how states should be governed. Confucius saw every aspect of life as being made up of obligations between people and entities, and rituals to convey the mutual dependency between them. His teachings focused on humanism, including treating others the way you would want to be treated. He taught that if everyone fulfilled their roles and obligations with respect and kindness towards others, it would build a stronger state. While religious rituals were mentioned alongside all of other rituals a person was expected to perform, Confucius did not focus on spiritual concerns like the afterlife, gods and goddesses or mysticism. This is why Confucianism is considered a philosophy rather than a religion, even though it is often lumped in with other major religions.

#china #archaeohistories #ancientchina #chinese #confucianism #historyfacts #chinesehistory #facts #taoism #buddhism

Caption:
🧾Sunday read 🧾⁠
⁠
⁠
Ge Hong: A Journey Toward Immortality⁠
⁠
Born in 283 C.E. near modern-day Nanjing, Ge Hong was raised in a prominent family. After his father's death, he faced adversity, driving him to seek wisdom in Confucian and Daoist teachings. He was skilled in martial arts and the quest for immortality, holding several military positions. Yet, his true passion lay in spiritual enlightenment over worldly power.⁠
⁠
In seclusion on Mount Luofu, Ge Hong wrote his masterpiece, Inner Chapters (Baopuzi), detailing paths to immortality through self-discipline, qi cultivation, and alchemy. He believed that true immortality required meditation, moral integrity, and understanding nature's secrets.⁠
⁠
Ge Hong sought to harmonize Taoism and Confucianism, promoting moral purity and blending Confucian ethics with legal structures. His ideas on immortality and the pursuit of knowledge have left a lasting legacy, illustrating how perseverance and learning can overcome adversity in a turbulent world.⁠
⁠
#GeHong #Daoism #Confucianism #AncientWisdom #Philosophy #Immortality #ChineseHistory #Alchemy #SpiritualJourney #MountLuofu #TaoApp⁠
⁠

Caption:
Got a copy of this Korean book on I-Ching divination and magic squares numerology today. The text is entirely written in Classical Chinese and comes with Korean pronunciation of the Chinese characters. Much of the theory seems to be derived from Song dynasty Neo-Confucian interpretations of I-Ching studies. The author Yi Sang-lyong mentions 朱子，程子 and 邵子, who I presume are Zhu Xi 朱熹, Cheng Yi 程頤 and Shao Yong 邵雍.

Title: 正易原義（정역원의 jeong yeok won ui）

Author: 李象龍（이상룡 Yi Sang-lyong; 1850 - 1899）

Caption:
EMPEROR WU: 
Emperor Wu of the Han Dynasty ruled China for 54 years between the 2nd and 1st centuries BCE. Although a warmonger, he was a big proponent of Confucianism, establishing the world's first official universities to teach it to his people. Despite Confucianism's social conservatism, though, Emperor Wu had several male lovers throught his life, but his strongest love was for a man named Han Yun.

They began a love affair together while both were still young, and upon ascension to emperor, Wu granted Han Yun undeserved prestigious titles and positions in government. The obvious favoritism caused much tension at court and made a hypocrite out of Wu who implemented the rule of promoting and bestowing rank based on academic excellence and skill instead of having the right connections. Ultimately, pressure from all sides forced Wu to mandate that Han Yu take his own life, ending the affair and his lover's undue place in government. . .

 #History #EmperorWu #HanDynasty #China #GayChina #QueerChina #LgbtChina #LgbtqChina #gay #queer #lgbt #lgbtq #queerhistory #ancientchina #chinesehistory #gayemperor #queeremperor #lgbtemperor #lgbtqemperor #gayhistory #lgbthistory #lgbtqhistory #confucianism #gayconfucianism #queerconfucianism #lgbtconfucianism #lgbtqconfucianism #HanYun #Wu #Zhongguo

Caption:
📍Thean Hou Temple, Kuala Lumpur

Thean Hou Temple is one of Southeast Asia’s largest and most magnificent temples. This 6-tiered temple incorporates Chinese architecture and style and is a combination of three beliefs: Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism. 

Its location atop Robson Hill makes it an ideal spot to rest and relax while seeing the magnificent Kuala Lumpur skyline from behind the temple’s stunning pagoda roofs.

Caption:
Recently, I found my life purpose. I kinda knew it, felt it in my gut, but always treated it like “not enough” because it had nothing to do with professional or financial goals, building a family, or creative ambitions – hello, ego – and yet it shapes all these spheres and gives me a sense of direction.

My purpose is to be the best version of myself and live my life in a way that moves me forward on this journey. I believe this is the best I can do with my life and the best attitude to live fully, freely, and happily.

How would I do this? Scroll the gallery!

PS: No, I would not punch a Stoic :) I would learn from one. Which I did actually, when I dated one. It made me more in control of my emotions. But dating a Stoic is not my jam. And now, with my purpose defined, I know why 😋

Caption:
關聖帝君寶誕
是日農曆六月二十四日是關聖帝君聖誕千秋。關聖帝君，是在三國時代蜀漢國的一位名將關羽，其忠義勇武為歷代所推崇，並多次被後代帝王褒封，直至武聖，也稱之為關聖帝、關帝君、關帝、關帝爺等。

崇拜關公已經歷千年演化，關公已經成為最具多元化的神明。除傳統的忠義象征之外，關公最為現代人看中的恐怕就是其武財神的身份了。

據說關公年輕時在家鄉從商販賣布匹，精於理財之道。關公所用的青龍偃月刀，十分鋒「利」，與生意上求「利」同音，求之獲「利」。合伙做生意最重義氣和信用，關公信義俱全，因此被後世商人尊為商業守護神，視關公為保佑人們發財的武財神。

關聖帝君誕辰拜祭供品：
熟三牲、鮮花、糕餅、茶三杯、酒三杯、蠟燭一對。

Caption:
Jade Turtles 🐢 

Properties: balance ⚖️ soothing, modesty 🙈 protection, harmony and stability 🧱 

Some info: Turtles are known to symbolize many things, from wisdom and knowledge 🧠 the moon 🌙 but also longevity and luck 🍀 In Canadian Indigenous populations, turtles are associated with the Earth 🌎 as in creation stories North America was created on the back of a turtle. This material, Jade 💚 has deep significance in Chinese cultures, being tied to wealth 💰 even being valued higher than gold. Jade is also associated with Confucianism, a belief system that places it's values on ethics, morality and justice 🟢

Both Turtles are the same size and weight and are SOLD OUT!

Comment or DM to claim! 🍋‍🟩

Caption:
Interested in cultivating beauty, love, happiness, and flourishing in life and the world?

Join the Life in Appreciation Workshop on August 3rd and 10th to explore the art of living as a window into appreciating and nurturing individuals as works of art.

The workshop will delve into fresh avenues for envisioning sustainable and equitable human flourishing through a variety of multisensory immersive experiences—audible, visual, gustatory, tactile, olfactory, and spatial/virtual reality.

For further information and registration, please direct message Vivienne @bviviennekim. This workshop is free and open to all.

Caption: Soul of a Sage. Mind of a King. Body of a Warrior.

🙌 Thirty Uzbekistani officials and scholars have been engaged in diverse learning and exploration activities in China this month! 

They discussed various topics in the field of culture and tourism and visited scenic spots and museums and libraries in #Beijing and #Shandong. They also attended the tenth #NishanForum on World Civilization, delving into #Confucianism with visits to the temple of Confucius. 👏

The activity was co-organized by Chinese Embassy in Uzbekistan, #BISU, and the Foreign Affairs Office of the Shandong Provincial People's Government. 

Stay tuned for more exciting cultural exchange activities!🤩

Caption:
Dosanseowon Confucian Academy 
UNESCO World Heritage Site

154, Dosanseowon-gil, Dosan-myeon, Andong-si, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Republic of Korea

Yi Hwang was a Korean philosopher, writer and Confucian scholar of the Joseon dynasty.
Considered the most important philosopher of Korea - he is honored by printing his portrait on the (most often used) 1000 Won banknote, on the reverse of which one can see an image of his school, Dosan Seowon.

 As Toegye was not wealthy, it took him four years to complete the construction of this building. A small signboard reading "Dosan Seowon", whose calligraphy Toegye he himself wrote, still hangings on one of the pillars at the end of Dosan Seodang.

Caption:
Dosanseowon Confucian Academy 
UNESCO World Heritage Site

154, Dosanseowon-gil, Dosan-myeon, Andong-si, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Republic of Korea

Dosan Seowon has 2 purposes
1 Education
2 Commemoration

Was well known in Korea as one of the leading academies and was home to the Toegye School of Thought for over 400 years. Although the educational function of the facility has long since ceased, the commemorative ceremonies have been and are still held twice a year.

Caption:
In our journey through life, it's easy to seek peace and happiness in external changes. 

We might think that a new job, a different house, or a change in our wardrobe will bring us the contentment we desire. However, true peace comes not from altering our external circumstances but from looking inward and facing ourselves.

To genuinely improve our lives, we must start by asking ourselves deep and probing questions. Who am I? What are my true values? What do I need to work on within myself to find inner peace?

Material possessions and changes can never truly transform who we are. They might provide temporary relief, but lasting fulfilment comes from self-improvement and understanding. 

Embrace the journey of facing your life exactly and completely, and you will discover a deeper, more profound peace.

Reflection Questions:
* How do you face the challenges in your life?
* What steps are you taking to understand yourself better?
* Have you experienced a moment when looking inward provided more peace than external changes?

I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences. Share them in the comments below.

#spiritualsunday #Mindfulness #SpiritualPractice #SelfAwareness #InnerPeace #DaininKatagiri #PhilosophicalReflection #Stoicism #Daoism #Buddhism #Confucianism #PersonalGrowth

Dalam ajaran Khonghucu, terdapat nilai-nilai luhur yang selalu kita junjung tinggi, seperti cinta kasih (仁 - rén), kebijaksanaan (智 - zhì), dan keberanian (勇 - yǒng). Nilai-nilai ini tidak hanya menjadi landasan moral, tetapi juga menjadi panduan dalam menjalankan tugas dan tanggung jawab sebagai penjaga negara dan pelindung masyarakat.

Dalam upacara pelantikan tersebut, Presiden Joko Widodo melantik 906 calon perwira remaja (capaja) sebagai perwira TNI-Polri. Rinciannya yakni 417 capaja dari Akademi Militer (Akmil), 129 capaja sari Akademi TNI Angkatan Laut (AAL), 113 capaja dari Akademi TNI Angkatan Udara (AAU) dan 247 capaja dari Akademi Kepolisian (Akpol).

Semoga dapat menjalankan tugas negara dengan sebaik-baiknya, melaksanakan amanat Presiden untuk dapat terus belajar seiring perkembangan zaman dan teknologi. Teruslah menjunjung tinggi nilai-nilai luhur tanah air serta kebajikan yang gemilang seperti yang Nabi Kongzi ajarkan dan juga dapat menjadi teladan bagi generasi muda Khonghucu lainnya.

Caption: Welcome to our new page! Snarky Buddha is a page dedicated to the academic study of religion!

"Yi Yuksa", a Korean poet and independence activist.
 A descendant of the scholar Yi Hwang, known as Toegye.

The Wide Plain

On a distant day,
When heaven first opened,
Somewhere a cock must have crowed.

No mountain ranges,
Rushing to the desired sea,
Could have dared to invade this land.

While the busy seasons gust and fade,
With endless time,
A great river first opens the way.

Now snow falls,
The fragrance of plum blossoms is far off,
I’ll sow the seed of my sad song here.

When a superman comes
On a white horse down the myriad years,
Let him sing aloud my song on the wide plain.

Caption:
赤崁楼のあとは、休憩を兼ねて、マンゴーかき氷でも食べようと思ったが、どこもかしこもたくさんの人が並んでいて、さすがに諦めた。やはり脳みそが溶けそうなくらいの暑さと日差しの強さなので、誰もが涼を取りたがっているからだろう。

そのまま次の観光ポイントである孔子廟まで、結局歩いてしまった。本当ならバスで移動すればよかったが、この二拠点間を移動できるようなバスがなかったからである。

台南の孔子廟はとにかく広くてでかい。清王朝時代は台湾唯一の最高学府であるため、多くの人がここで学んでいたからである。しかし、今となっては、学ぶと言ってもどこで学んでいたんだろうという疑問がある。別に机があったり、それを納める場所があるわけでもないからだ。

それにしても孔子廟の中にある建物に、たくさんの扁額があるのだが、これ、多すぎませんか？論語の教えの抜粋なのか、それとも学生の心得を示したものなのかよくわからない。

敷地内には明倫堂という建物があるのだが、ここに入ると学生の心得が記載されている臥碑が目の前に出てくる。そして、四方の壁には忠孝節義の四文字がバラバラに大きく書かれている。

外に出ると三重塔の存在が確認できる。この塔、よく見ると不思議な建物で、1階は四角形、2階は円形、3階は八角形の構造になっている。ここは科挙に合格するための願掛けが行われたところである。

科挙という国家公務員になれれば一生一族安泰となるほどのものであったが、その競争率はものすごい高い。科挙のことは別に記載したいがここでは書くことはやめる。

赤崁樓之後，本來想休息一下，吃個芒果剉冰，但到處都是人，只好放棄。因為實在太熱，太陽太毒，大家都想找地方涼快一下。

最後只好走到下一個景點孔子廟。本來想搭公車，但這兩個景點之間並沒有直達的公車。

台南的孔子廟非常廣大。在清朝時期，這裡是台灣唯一的最高學府，許多人在這裡學習。不過現在回想起來，不禁疑惑當時是在哪裡學習的。這裡並沒有什麼課桌椅或教室之類的設施。

此外，孔子廟內掛著很多匾額，數量之多讓人感到驚訝。不知道這些匾額是論語中的名句，還是學生的心得。

在孔子廟裡有一座名叫明倫堂的建築，進去之後可以看到記載著學生心得的臥碑。而四面牆上則分別寫著「忠」、「孝」、「節」、「義」四個大字。

走出來可以看到三重塔。這座塔很有意思，一樓是方形，二樓是圓形，三樓是八角形。這裡曾是人們祈求科舉考試合格的地方。

科舉考試是非常重要的，通過之後便可成為官員，保障家族一生的安泰，但競爭非常激烈。關於科舉的詳細內容在這裡就不多說了。

Caption:
📍The Wisdom Path, Lantau Island
What an incredible feeling it is to walk among wooden columns, that are similar in form and intention to Zhujian (bamboo tiles) that have been traditionally used for writing in ancient times! Before you is a fairly recent piece, completed in 2005, but which pays homage to a rich history of art, literature, and philosophy. This is a calligraphic work based on the Heart Sutra, a text important to Confucianists, Buddhists, and Taoists. There are 38 columns out of timber, which are arranged in the shape of the figure eight, the infinity sign, and match the layout and the topography of the landscape with their careful arrangement. The highest column,not featured in my photo collection unfortunately, is blank, to reference the key concept of emptiness in the Sutra. 

This wisdom path is near Ngong Ping of Lantau Island, close to the Big Buddha. The Heart Sutra is a concise work of just 260 words, and to see the beautiful calligraphy on the 8 x10 towering wood is a sight that is a must see for those who admire ancient texts, calligraphy, and beautiful nature. Close to Ngong Ping is also a fishing village called Tai O, which is over 200 years old, and many here keep to the traditional ways of life, lots of fishing market stalls, traditional street food, and houses on stilts. If you wish to be transported back in time, this is for sure worth combining with your visit to the wisdom path. There is also a cute cafe located next to an even cuter cat cafe which has some good books that are decorated with stickers, making for a super unique and atmospheric reading experience. Scroll through to see my postcards from Lantau Island, and this was my Day 2 in Hong Kong💗

Caption:
Ketua Umum MATAKIN Xs. Budi S. Tanuwibowo 陈清明 menghadiri Forum Peradaban Dunia Nishan ke-10 dibuka di Nishan, Qufu, serta membawakan makalah dengan tema “Kecerdasan AI dan peradaban manusia”.

Acara ini diadakan pada tanggal 10-11 Juli 2024 kali ini bertujuan untuk mendorong transformasi kreatif dan perkembangan inovatif budaya tradisional Tiongkok yang unggul, serta memajukan peradaban manusia melalui pertukaran dan pembelajaran yang mendalam yang mengimplementasikan pemikiran Xi Jinping. 

Lebih dari 700 tamu dari dalam dan luar negeri berkumpul di kampung halaman Zhisheng Kongzi untuk membahas budaya tradisional dan peradaban modern, menyuarakan "Suara Nishan", serta memberikan kontribusi kebijaksanaan untuk mempraktikkan inisiatif peradaban global, mempromosikan nilai-nilai bersama umat manusia, dan membangun komunitas dengan masa depan bersama bagi umat manusia.

Caption:
🗿The Dazu Rock Carvings: a harmonious expression of Buddhism, Taoism and Confucianism🗿

Explore the Dazu Rock Carvings, a UNESCO World Heritage site located on the steep hillsides of Dazu. Dating from the 9th to the 13th century, these rock carvings are celebrated for their grand scale, aesthetic excellence, and rich diversity of both secular and religious themes. They offer a glimpse into daily life and spiritual practices of ancient China, highlighting the harmonious coexistence of Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism.

One remarkable cave at Dazu features statues of Confucius, the Three Pure Ones, and Shakyamuni. This unique combination showcases the blending of Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism, reflecting the philosophical and religious fusion that occurred in China over centuries. These carvings provide an example of how these three major schools of thought were harmoniously integrated into Chinese culture.

The Dazu Rock Carvings integrate scenes from everyday life into religious narratives. Noteworthy examples include the "Transformation Tableau of Parents' Benevolence" and the "Transformation Tableau of the Great Requital of the Buddha." Within the heritage site, you'll encounter elegant statues of Guanyin, serene Buddhas, respectful donor figures, lifelike depictions of drunken individuals, and intricately detailed incense burners. These carvings are a testament to the blending of various artistic influences and the skilled craftsmanship of their creators.

Plan your visit to Dazu and step into a world where history, art, and spirituality come together in perfect harmony.

Caption:
Confucius (circa 551–479 BCE) was a Chinese government official and its most important philosopher. 

He founded Confucianism, a school of thought so influential that it’s sometimes seen as a religion in China. 

Unlike prophets of other faiths, Confucius said almost nothing about gods—he was not interested in mysticism, and the ideological system he created is not a set of religious rules, but a grand moral and ethical instruction on proper behavior.

Caption:
⠀⠀
Traditions and customs are like the forces that sustain the times. Traditions and customs that contain the aspirations and wills of ancestors become an order that makes the world maintained.
But science and technology develop and the culture of the times changes.
Naturally, traditions and customs must change gradually according to the times while maintaining their essential parts.
However, if only form remains in Korean Confucianism's ceremonies and their contents are not understood at all in the present time, it will be a form of coercion that does not want to be done.
Wouldn't it be possible to understand the absurdities, bad practices, and evils rooted in the community in this way? Aren't the ritual forms, which are now only shells, filled with content they intend to use to satisfy their self-interest?
And isn’t that being packaged as an “order”?
This must be flowing in a different direction from the aspirations of the ancestors.

전통과 관습은 마치 시대를 지탱하는 힘과 같다.
조상들의 염원과 의지가 담긴 전통과 관습은
세상을 유지하도록 만드는 하나의 질서가 된다.

그러나 과학기술은 발전하고 시대문화는 변화한다.

당연히 전통과 관습도
본질적인 부분은 유지한 채로
시대에 맞춰 조금씩 변화해야 한다.

그러나 대한민국 유교의 관혼상제 같은 의식이
형식만이 남아버려 그 내용들이
현시대에 전혀 이해되지 않는다면
이는 일종의 하기 싫은 강요와 같은 형태가 될 것이다.

공동체 내에 뿌리내린 부조리, 악습, 폐단도
이와 같은 방식으로 이해할 수 있지 않을까?
껍데기만 남아버린 의례적인 형식들에
그저 자신들의 사리사욕만을 채우기 위해
이용하려는 내용들이 담긴 것 아닌가?

그리고 그걸 "질서"라고 포장하는 것 아닌가?

이는 조상들이 꿈꾸던 염원과는
분명 다른 방향으로 흘러가고 있을 것이다.

忍唔到手打咗下睇下好唔好聲

Caption:
SAN JIAO 三教

In Chinese philosophy, the three teachings, or “Sān Jiào”, are Daoism, Buddhism and Confucianism.

The three teachings reflect a long history, characterized by mutual influence and complementary teachings of the three belief systems, but often also by conflicts. All Chinese culture is based on the San Jiao. They are represented with the faces of their main exponents: Confucius, Buddha, Laozi.

Confucianism is a school of thought that revolves around the thoughts of Confucius, with attention to morality, education, respect for ancestors and politics.

Buddhism is a religious culture founded in India by Siddharta Gautama between the 6th and 5th centuries BC. The goal of the Buddhist spiritual path is to achieve complete liberation from suffering through spiritual practice.

Daoism is a complex and ancient culture that developed in China and aims to follow the Dao, the universal principle of all things, an indeterminate entity that represents the continuous change of nature and its alternation between positive and negative phases.

#sanjiao #threefaith #daoism #confucianism #buddhism

Caption:
Confucius 
The Five Constant Virtues of Confucianism are:
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Ren (仁): “benevolence” or “humaneness,” Ren represents an attitude of kindness and compassion towards others. It is the fundamental virtue that embodies the moral integrity and selflessness expected in human interactions.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Yi (義): “righteousness” or “justice,” Yi signifies the importance of doing what is morally right and just. It involves acting with integrity and upholding ethical principles, even in the face of personal sacrifice.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Li (禮): “ritual propriety” or “etiquette,” emphasizes the importance of maintaining proper conduct, manners, and respect in social interactions. Li includes adherence to traditional rituals and ceremonies that foster social harmony.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Zhi (智): “wisdom” or “knowledge,” Zhi represents the ability to make sound judgments and decisions based on a deep understanding of moral principles and the world. It is the intellectual virtue that guides ethical behavior.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Xin (信): “trustworthiness” or “faithfulness,” Xin denotes the virtue of being reliable and honest. It involves maintaining sincerity and trust in relationships, ensuring that one’s words and actions are consistent and dependable.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
#Confucius #Confucianism #ChinesePhilosophy #FiveConstantVirtues
Hashtags: ChinesePhilosophy, Confucianism, Confucius, FiveConstantVirtues

Caption:
The Xi'an Beilin Museum is expanded from the historic Xi'an Confucian Temple complex, which traces its origins back to the early Tang Dynasty (618-907).✨

Today, the Xi'an Confucian Temple retains the basic scale and iconic structures of its Ming and Qing dynasty (1368-1911) predecessors. The towering archways, the quaint Panchi Pond, the solemn Lingxing Gate, and the majestic Ji Gate all reflect the grandeur and magnificence of the temple's past.✨

In Korea, the color red is associated with positive energy and good fortune.

In the Joseon Dynasty, crown princes were educated at the Seonggyungwan, the highest educational institution, where they studied Confucian classics, history, poetry, and governance. This strict training served as a way to prepare them to be wise and just rulers with moral integrity and intellectual excellence!

Caption:
天 (tiān) : heaven, sky, the natural order
道 (dào) : way, path, principle, the way things are meant to be
酬 (chóu) : to reward, to repay
勤 (qín) : diligence, hard work, industriousness

The idiom "天道酬勤" translates to "Heaven rewards the diligent." This phrase emphasizes the value of persistent effort and industriousness, suggesting that those who work hard and remain dedicated will eventually be rewarded for their endeavors. Its concept is rooted in the belief that there is a natural justice or balance in the universe that favors and compensates those who are diligent and hardworking. It is often used to encourage perseverance and dedication in the pursuit of one's goals.

Caption:
寧 (níng) : calm, peaceful, tranquil
靜 (jìng) : quiet, still, silent
致 (zhì) : to achieve, to reach, to lead to
遠 (yuǎn) : far, distant, long-term

The idiom "寧靜致遠" translates to "tranquility leads to far-reaching goals." It conveys the idea that maintaining inner peace and a calm demeanor is essential for achieving significant and enduring accomplishments. This concept is deeply rooted in Chinese philosophical traditions, particularly in Confucianism and Daoism, where inner tranquility is considered the foundation for external success and fulfillment.

Caption:
A stunning addition to our collection! 🦆

During the Joseon Dynasty (1392-1897), "wedding ducks" were essential in traditional weddings. These intricately carved ducks, given by the groom to the bride's family, symbolised respect, fidelity, and a harmonious union. The positioning of the ducks served as a non-verbal communication tool: facing each other indicated harmony and mutual respect, while turned away suggested a need for resolving disagreements. 

#weddingducks #koreanantiques #antique #confucianism #joseondinasty #hancollection #gallery #koreanart

Caption:
The data European societies gained about China until the early modern era (1500s-1600s) may be considered spurious at most. In particular, reliable data on Confucianism was even rarer. Marco Polo’s journeys were not only of dubious realism, but also took place within a time frame in which China was ruled by the Mongol Yuan, who largely did not represent native Chinese philosophical traditions. It was only at the end of the sixteenth and beginning of the seventeenth century, when Matteo Ricci and his cooperating Jesuit priest-scholars delivered first translations of Chinese classics. They led to the Europeans’ idealization of China as a country “ruled by worthies”. In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, however, the enlightenment, scientific progress, European imperialism and Opium Wars changed the Old World’s perception of the Middle Kingdom into one of disdain and pity.

.
.
.
.
.
.

Caption:
Temple of Confucius and Guozijian Museum
孔廟·國子監

✏️Guozijian, also translated as Imperial College. It served as the supreme administrative headquarters of the organization of education. Flanked by the Temple of Confucius and Yonghe Lamasery, it is located at 15 Guozijian Street (originally named Chengxian Street). 

Facing south, it is the only imperial college from ancient times still preserved. It is a remarkable architectural complex, with over one hundred buildings. Jixian Gate (the front gate), Taixue Gate (the second gate), the glazed archway, Biyong Hall, Yilun Hall and Jingyi Pavilion are located along a central axis. On the east and west sides of the main building four halls and six palaces were laid out to achieve a symmetrical effect of perfect unity.

按“左庙右学”而建，左庙既孔庙，右学既国子监，国子监是古代最高学府和教育机构，两者本就紧紧相邻，且主题比较相近，如今作为同一个景区对外开放。

⏰08:30-18:00（17:00停止售票）
🎫成人全价票30元/人，学生半价票15元/人
🚇地铁2号线/5号线至雍和宫站下车
🗺️东侧孔庙先师门（进士题名碑） 大成门 中院（东西两侧为大哉孔子展）大成殿（孔庙主建筑） 干隆石经展（从这个展厅穿过去，来到国子监） 太学门 琉璃牌楼（牌坊后面有”独占鳌头“瑞兽）一辟雍殿（四面环水，可喂锦鲤） 从国子监出

Caption:
Besides the purpose and place of the event, the Ghost Festival also has ritual objects! 

These are several things that are used during Ghost Festival: 

1. Lantern, to light the path for our ancestors to come back home

2. Offerings, for our good deeds by giving food to ancestors and people around us

3. Coin Poe Divination, to communicate with ancestors (poe blocks are used specifically for Buddhas,  Bodhisattvas, and deities) 

4. Shoyo Uma & Shoryo Ushi, a representation of a ride that our ancestors used from the land of the dead to the living (Eggplant = Buffalo, Cucumber = Horse)

5. Paper Statue of Gui Wang, a giant statue made out of colorful paper for the Ghost King deity that protects us from naughty spirits

6. Tai Su Statue, a statue of Heibai Wuchang that is placed on the temple altar for ancestors, we believe that Heibai Wuchang is the one who gave our ancestors food spiritually from the altar's offerings 

✴✴✴

Caption:
Since y'all already know a bit about Ghost Festival, I want to share where this festival is held!

As you can see, this festival is not tied to one place. It is held in:

1. Cemetery, with a purpose to clean and take care of our ancestors' graveyard 

2. Monastery, for Buddhists to hold a ceremony and pray for all sentient beings

3. Temple, for Confucianists and Taoists to hold a ceremony and pray for their ancestors

4. Home, where we spend our time with families and pray together

5. Bon Odori, celebrated in Japan as a cultural event and to honor our ancestors

6. Getai Show, extremely famous in Singapore! Usually held near a graveyard to entertain souls with local Hokkien and Chinese songs

Caption:
Have you ever heard of Ghost Festival?

In my area, it is commonly known as 'Sembahyang Rebutan'. This festival celebrates the arrival of our ancestors from the afterlife to the living world just like Dia De Los Muertos in Coco Disney movie! 

This festival is a religious event celebrated by Buddhists, Taoists, Confucianists, and Shintoists. It has various names in several Asian countries as well 🪷

Caption:
já que é quinta-feira e quinta é dia de #tbt vou aproveitar o gancho pra compartilhar umas fotos que o Davi me fez resgatar.⁣
⁣
ontem estávamos estudando ciências e ensino religioso. depois de falarmos sobre matéria, estados da matéria e suas transformações, cobrimos o que algumas religiões entendem por FELICIDADE. lindo né?⁣
⁣
é tão difícil falar de religiões que eu conheço pouco ou que não conheço ninguém que pratica. eu sempre tive uma curiosidade religiosa, que me trouxe um encantamento por religiões que não são minhas, seus rituais, seus templos, como as pessoas se encaixam nisso tudo. ⁣
⁣
então sempre que eu posso visitar algum lugar sagrado de uma religião diferente, eu vou! e foi assim na China.⁣
⁣
ontem eu pude mostrar pro Davi os templos budistas, taoístas e confucionista que visitamos em Shanghai. as fotos do carrossel são do Wen Miao, o único templo confucionista em Shanghai. como o confucionismo em si não é uma religião, o templo hoje é uma referência acadêmica. ⁣
⁣
#shanghai #confucian #confucius #confucianism
Hashtags: confucius, tbt, confucianism, shanghai, confucian

Caption:
World's Oldest Civilization and Religion 

पूरे इतिहास में आध्यात्मिक परंपराएं उतनी ही तेजी से प्रकट हुई हैं जितनी जल्दी वे लुप्त हो गईं। जबकि अधिकांश धर्म यह उपदेश देते हैं कि उनकी शिक्षाएँ समय की शुरुआत से ही हैं, यह केवल कुछ प्राचीन धर्म हैं जो समय की कसौटी पर खरे उतरे हैं। आज, दुनिया के कुछ सबसे पुराने धर्म अभी भी चलन में हैं। इस कारण धर्म के अध्ययन का एक भी इतिहास मौजूद नहीं है।

1. शुद्ध वैष्णव ۞✡𑁍卐卍🛞⍟✚(Pure Vashnav The way of life, Jambudweep million years old)– Origin: Bharat Bharatvarsh Indus River Valley Mohenjo-Daro and Harappa (Modern-Day Pakistan), Circa 8,000 BCE (ओ३म् Sanskrit Vedic Om) 
भारतवर्ष के प्रथम मंदिर का नाम हरिभ्रमण था. वैदिक संस्कृति

आईआईटी-खड़गपुर और भारतीय पुरातत्व सर्वेक्षण (एएसआई) के वैज्ञानिकों ने इस बात के सबूत खोजे हैं कि सिंधु घाटी सभ्यता कम से कम 8,000 साल पुरानी है, न कि 5,500 साल पुरानी, जिसकी जड़ें मिस्र (7000 ईसा पूर्व से 3000 ईसा पूर्व) और मेसोपोटामिया (6500 ईसा पूर्व से 6500 ईसा पूर्व) से काफी पहले थीं। 3100 ईसा पूर्व)

2. Greek Religion– ✚ Origin: greek 2500-1050 BCE

3. Judaism – ✡ Origin: Southern Levant (Modern-Day Israel,  Palestine, And Jordan), Circa 2,000 BCE

4. Zoroastrianism – 𔓙 Origin:  Ancient Persia (Modern-Day Iran), Circa 1,500 BCE

5. Buddhism हीनयान – 卐卍۞🛞 Origin: Indian Subcontinent (Modern-Day Nepal), Circa 483 BCE to 563 BCE

6. Jainism – 卐🪬 Origin: India, Circa 483 BCE to 600 BCE
प्राचीन काल में जैन धर्म को आर्हत् धर्म कहा जाता था।

7. Yazidism – 🦚✚ Origin:  Ancient Persia (Modern-Day Middle East) Circa 1,500 BCE _ Lord Kartikeya

 8. Shinto – ⛩️ Origin: Japan, Circa 700 BCE

 9. Confucianism –Taoism – ☯ Origin: China, Circa 500 BCE- 600 BCE

📌 हीनयान प्रथम बौद्ध धर्म: वह बौद्ध धर्म के प्राचीन आदर्शों को यथावत बनाये रखना चाहता था। हीनयान संप्रदाय के सभी ग्रंथ पाली भाषा में लिखे गए हैं। हीनयान बुद्ध को भगवान के रूप में नहीं पूजते थे बल्कि बुद्ध को केवल एक महापुरुष मानते थे। हीनयान की प्रथा बहुत सख्त थी और वह मठवासी जीवन का रक्षक था।

Caption:
Has the monsoon finally arrived in Mumbai? I think it has, and after a dramatic night of thunder, lightning, and the welcome respite of a steady downpour, the quiet aftermath of this morning is bathed in freshness.

And this beautiful, quiet, metaphorically cobweb-free dawn was the perfect setting to do justice to *The Oxherd Boy*. Through the intricate yet delicate strokes of the Chinese Gongbi painting technique, the author goes along with a young farmer boy, his family ox, and a rabbit found in the garden, to give us a parable based on the three pillars of Chinese philosophy: Taoism, Buddhism, and Confucianism.

The life-lessons sparsely gracing each page on love, family, community, the power of imagination and creativity, the innate need to have a kind heart in a world that is steadily growing more cynical with each day, dealing with pain, heartbreak, uncertainty, loss and its aftermath, and the quiet solace of just lending a willing ear rather than unsolicited advice are nuggets of wisdom as old as time.

And yet, there is such a heartbreaking clarity in the wizened gaze of the smiling ox, the puckish charm of the can-do rabbit, and the philosophical observations of the solemn little boy, yet untouched by the ways of the world.

I am a fool for exquisite illustrations, and this book awash in soft brush strokes and exquisite detail, coupled with those little familiar gems that we need to hear every now and then, will have a permanent place in my home library.

On days when I can’t understand people and their motives, on days when I can’t fathom myself and my hopes, my expectations, and my disappointments, I will return to this book….stroll languorously through a rice field with the boy, the ox, and the rabbit.

And make peace with my demons.

Caption:
🇬🇧 Beijing Confucius Temple ⬇️

• The Confucius Temple in Beijing (北京孔庙 Běijīng Kǒngmiào) was initially built in 1302 during the Yuan Dynasty, and got bigger during the Ming and Dynasties.

• Covering an area of over 22,000 square meters, it is the second largest Confucius temple, following the one in Qufu, Confucius birthplace, in Shandong.

• Located in close proximity to the Imperial Academy, the temple was historically used for ceremonies to honour Confucius, as well as a place for scholars to study and pay homage.

• Nowadays, it is still a temple dedicated to Confucius, but it is also a museum and cultural site that highlights Confucian thinking and education in the imperial times.

• The temple houses 198 stone tablets inscribed with the names of more than 50,000 scholars from the Yuan, Ming, and Qing dynasties, but also tablets which commemorate the scholars who passed the imperial examinations, as well as historical steles.

• Who is Confucius?
Confucius (Kǒngzǐ 孔子, 551-479 BCE) was a great Chinese philosopher whose ideas deeply influenced China and Chinese culture. He is regarded as the first teacher/educator of China, a model of wisdom and virtue, and his thinking founded Confucianism.

• His teachings have been compiled by his disciples in the “Analects” (Lunyu 论语) and they emphasize on morality, sincerity, justice, wisdom, filial piety and social harmony.

Caption:
The concept of yin and yang has deep historical roots and has evolved significantly over time. Originating around the 14th century BC, these ideas were first found on oracle bones used for divination in ancient China. Initially, yin represented night and darkness, while yang symbolised day and light. By the 3rd century BC, yin was associated with darkness and the north side of mountains, and yang with brightness and the south side.

During the Han and Zhou Dynasties, the philosophical interpretations of yin and yang flourished, especially with the integration of qi, or vital energy. Philosophers like Confucius and Lao Tzu expanded on these ideas. Lao Tzu’s Tao Te Ching describes the creation and interdependence of all things through yin and yang, illustrating how these forces blend to produce harmony.

Yin is associated with darkness, nourishment, cool, dampness, Earth, Autumn, and Winter. Yang is linked to brightness, strength, dryness, heat, Heaven, Spring, and Summer. These opposing forces are in constant flux, each containing the seed of the other. 

In Chinese medicine, yin and yang is utilised to categorise in various ways, whether it be the three treasures, body areas and depths, organs and pathogens. Maintaining a balance between yin and yang is key to sustaining harmonious health. Chinese medicine aims to achieve this balance, while also accepting that balance will always change into something else!

#YinYang #ChineseMedicine #AncientWisdom #BalanceAndHarmony #Philosophy #Taoism #Confucianism #Qi #TraditionalMedicine #HealthAndWellness #HolisticHealth
Hashtags: Philosophy, Taoism, HealthAndWellness, Confucianism, ChineseMedicine, BalanceAndHarmony, HolisticHealth, Qi, YinYang, TraditionalMedicine, AncientWisdom

Caption:
求學期間，曾無數次從大學圖書館走到科學館下，「煲底」；這次卻異常地莊嚴。

科學館的建築上刻有中大校徽：一隻紫金相間的鳳凰。傳說中，鳳凰會浴火重生，是鎮守南方的神獸。〈人間世〉結尾有一句慨嘆：「鳳兮鳳兮，何如德之衰也！來世不可待，往世不可追也。」強如鳳凰，在衰敗的時代也要退讓三分：不能陶醉於昔日的榮景，也不應盲目等待未來的好日子。

中大的創校學者，多是從中日戰爭、國共內戰以來離鄉背井，抵達香港。學者要在難民潮、西式高等教育的夾縫中，奮鬥二十年，才等到中文大學成立的一天，獲得安定的環境著書立說、作育英才——專注當下，堅韌不拔，是鳳凰重生的前提。傾向出世的莊子，借助鳳凰保存入世的信念。

科學館外露的混凝土支柱，把校徽浮雕上的鳳凰，活靈活現地推向天空。導賞當天陰雨綿綿，鳳凰的紫色低調地顯示它的尊貴，金色卻似成爲照亮整片天空的唯一燭光。我在煲底，感受到莊子、中大創校學者、鳳凰心底的熊熊烈火。

活動由一九八一新亞中文系校友中華文化基金、博群社會企業起動計劃資助。
